questions.question_text: A switch is being configured for installation into a new building. The network design is such that the only DHCP server resides in the datacenter. A traditional three-layer network hierarchy is being used, and all buildings have a Layer 3 connection back to the core. Which of the following should the technician configure to get DHCP working properly in the new building?

choices.C: The IP helper address on the switch
choices.A: The SMTP relays in the datacenter
choices.D: The ARP forwarding on the switch

discussion.content:
One level above DHCP relay is IP helper. These two terms are often used as
synonyms, but they are not; a better way to think of it is with IP helper being a
superset DHCP relay. IP helper will, by default, forward broadcasts for
DHCP/BOOTP, TFTP, DNS, TACACS, the time service, and the NetBIOS
name/datagram service (ports 137â€“139). You can disable the additional traffic
(or add more), but by default IP helper will do more than a DHCP relay

questions.question_text: A network administrator notices a wireless network with the SSID HOME-33BC-5G that has a high signal strength and open authentication. When the administrator connects to the SSID, corporate servers can be accessed. Which of the following has the network administrator discovered?

discussion.content:
"A rogue access point is specifically an AP inside a network not administered by the network owner, giving it unwanted access to network.

An evil twin is a copy of a legitimate access point not necessarily giving it access to a specific network or even to internet."

comments.content: Sure, but an Evil Twin is trying to copy a legitimate access point. If you look at the SSID, it's called "Home-33BC-5G", even though it seems to be in the internal company network. This isn't someone trying to copy an existing internal corporate SSID to trick people into connecting, this is an AP that is trying to pretend to be some home network, though it's being used as a way for someone from the outside to connect into the company's resources.
An evil twin copies an existing SSID, the SSID being displayed was not for a server, but a home network. Rogue ap is the answer

discussion.content:
Isn't the answer to this question either (A) or (D). A rogue AP is effectively the same as an "evil twin" that is an AP masquerading as a legitimate AP to lure users to connect.

"An evil twin, in security, is a rogue wireless access point that masquerades as a legitimate Wi-Fi access point so that an attacker can gather personal or corporate information without the end-user's knowledge."

Any suggestions?

questions.question_text: A network technician is working on a new wireless project. The network manager has a primary requirement of achieving speeds of at least 1 Gbps when connected. Which of the following standards would be appropriate for the technician to implement?

discussion.content:
802.11a 5 GHz 54 Mbit/s
 802.11b 2.4 GHz 11 Mbit/s
 802.11g 2.4 GHz 54 Mbit/s
 802.11n 5 GHz and/or 2.4 GHz 600 Mbit/s
 802.11ac 5 GHz ~6.8 Gbit/s

questions.question_text: A network technician is attempting to update firmware on a router but cannot physically locate the router. Which of the following would show where to locate router?

comments.content: if it said physical diagram i would say yes. logical might not have physical location. Really the rack is the only one that may show the location.
This was my first guess, but assuming the router is located in the mdf, rack diagram is the appropriate answer.

discussion.content: might be the gateway 1 so answer may be c
can someone tell me what resources i should study to answer all types of IP related questions.thanks in advance
Can someone explain to me why answer is C

comments.content:
which of the devices then takes 192.168.1.0
I was thinking that should be the routers address
It's basically reserved, first and last IP addresses in this network are reserved. First one at .0 is network, last one is broadcast
No device can 192.168.0 because that is the network address. Every first IP address in a range of a subnet is always the network address.

For every subnet, you have two IP addresses that are not usable. The first address is the network address, and the last address in the subnet is the broadcast address.

The network address will take 192.168.1.0. The first usable address will be 192.168.1.1 which is what will be assigned to the router (gateway). The broadcast address for this subnet is 192.168.1.255.

The subnet mask is /24 which means that this is a classfull ip address so traditionally the router would be the first IP address in the node space which is 192.168.1.1. The broadcast address would be the last IP in the node space which is 192.168.1.255. The nodes on the subnet which would be devices would populate the 192.168.1.2 - 192.168.1.254 space.

questions.question_text: A technician is trying to determine the IP address of a customer's router. The customer has an IP address of 192.168.1.55/24. Which of the following is the address of the customer's router?
